reviews.text: My husband and I stayed here on business recently. Like the previous reviewers, we found this place to be a nice (but not stellar) boutique hotel in downtown Portland. Its in a great location - within walking distance of most of the city and near the fareless tram lines. The staff is friendly and helpful (despite some billing mistakes, which were quickly remedied) and the food was adequate. I thought the room was well-appointed and cozy, though small. Surprisingly, the bathrooms are rather large in comparison. Nice Aveda amenities, very clean (super nice and efficient house-keeping staff), etc. But overall, kind of boring, average and not very unique. Like a previous reviewer, we too were placed on a floor that was practically teeming with photos of prominent Republicans. I understand the concept behind the photography exhibition throughout the hotel, but still found the number of photos to be a little unnerving, plus having so many together on one floor really gave the impression that the hotel had some kind of agenda. Had I known about the photos on our floor beforehand, I would have at least requested to be on another floor. Despite our nice stay, we'll be staying at the new Ace Hotel on our next visit.
reviews.title: Portland's Best - Details & Service = A+++

reviews.text: I stayed at the Hotel Lucia on March 17, 2007. It was my first trip to Portland--which was, incidentally, full of exquisitely blooming trees that weekend--and I'd gotten the sense that the Lucia was the newest and most attractive of the city's boutique hotels, so I decided to pay the $150 for a room there. My experience was mixed. First, the good part: the rooms are beautifully lit--there's almost too little light, but it's genuinely warm and welcoming--and the linens and toiletries are all what you'd expect. (I was even introduced to some Aveda product I'd never tried before, and I'm an Aveda fanatic.) But my room was *painfully* small, about the size of the Hudson in New York (maybe 150 square feet); in Portland it seemed gratuitously tiny. This wouldn't have been a problem if there hadn't also been nearly constant noise from the hallway, as other people returned from their St Patrick's Day nights out, some of them with a lot of shouting. A hotel doesn't have a lot of control over guest behavior, I realize, but it can make design decisions that privilege quiet; the Lucia did not make these decisions. The infuriating part of my experience was, however, the following morning: when I brought up my lack of sleep with the front desk attendant at checkout, and said that I would not be staying at the Lucia again, nor recommending it to my friends (many of whom end up in Portland occasionally), the guy just smiled at me and said, inexplicably, "Thank you." I said, "No, I don't think you understood me. I *won't* be staying here or recommending it to other people." He smiled again, shyly--it wasn't a language comprehension question, his English was clearly just fine--and handed me the bill, and I knew that it was hopeless. Transparent walls are one thing; unresponsive customer service--how much would an apology have hurt?--is unforgivable. Seriously, folks: I love independent boutique hotels, and have stayed in my share of them, but I've never seen this kind of blithe indifference to a guest's problems with his or her stay. My advice: if you're hearing-impaired, can sleep through anything, have a thick skin, and are very thin (for dealing with the room's tight corners), you may want to consider this place; otherwise, you may want to look elsewhere.

reviews.text: I stayed here in December 2006 and absolutely LOVED the hotel! I was greeted in my room with a beautiful little chocolate from a nearby cafe, and a bottle of gorgeous VOSS water. The room was tastefully decorated, and everything was just so plush and inviting that it really felt like an urban sanctuary. Remember to bring you iPod - the alarm clock is an iHome system that you can dock your iPod on, so you enjoy some music while you relax in your room! The wireless worked perfectly, making my business travel easy. The honor bar was stocked with every kind of goodie imaginable, and overall, I loved my experience here. I would definitely stay here again just for the lovely room. It's also really close to shopping in Portland, which is a bonus.

reviews.title: Comfort and ease

reviews.text: The hotel is a lovely old building restored to an Art Deco/Midcentury modern aesthetic. It's apparently one of the few non-chain hotels in the city. Location is good, a couple of blocks from the Pearl trolley line and the Max. We booked via the Portland Big Deal (google it) and were pleasantly surprised. Our queen room was a bit on the small side, but so are many of the grand dames of the hotel world, like the Fairmont or the Awahnee. The bed, pillows and linens were cushy and luxurious. Service was good, the rate was reasonable and parking is included, no small thing in any city. Breakfast in the dining room (Thyphoon?) was very good, from a Thai-inspired chicken egg crepe to biscuits and gravy.

reviews.title: Probably overrated but not bad

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: After having stayed here I'm not sure what all the fuss is about. There was nothing wrong but there was nothing, except for a slightly hipper than average decor, that sets this place apart from many other hotels. The room itself was tiny. Basically contained a king bed and enough room to edge around it. The furnishings were fairly modern and there was a flat screen TV and a cool radio that had an ipod dock. The overall decor was kind of cool with very interesting photos throughout the room, hallways and elevators.
reviews.title: Great service at Hotel Lucia

reviews.text: The big plus was that the service was outstanding. When we arrived our room wasn't yet ready but we were able to leave our bags and have our car parked. As soon as the room was ready (more than an hour before they told us it would be ready) they called to let us know. When we got back they recognized us on sight, passed along our key and let us know our luggage had already been brought up. Front desk folks were very good in offering maps and help with driving and walking directions. When we checked out the parking valet quickly brought our car as well as two bottles of water for the road.
reviews.title: Good hotel with one big drawback

reviews.text: Overall I can't complain about the experience and would likely return to the hotel. Though I don't think the hotel merits the accolades it seems to have received it does have more character than a standard chain hotel (Hilton, Marriott, etc). The only reason to avoid it would be if you felt you needed a big roomy room.

reviews.text: I found the front desk people to be very helpful and the doorpeople were incredibly friendly as well. I had a queen sized corner room on the ninth floor and was very satisifed with the size of the room. Perhaps I lucked out getting a corner room and possibly the rooms on higher floors are larger (I don't know) but compared to my usual hotel rooms in New York and San Francisco, this was very large. The bed was very comfortable and I did not hear my neighbors at all.
